Definitions.Definition_Content: An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Given a subset \(U \subset \bar{K}^{n}\), the corresponding ideal \(I(U)\) in the polynomial ring \(K[X]\) consists of all polynomials that vanish on \(U\).

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).

Theorems.Theorem_Content: For ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1}, \mathfrak{a}_{2}\), respectively a family \(\left(\mathfrak{a}_{i}\right)_{i \in I}\) of ideals in \(K[X]\), and for subsets \(U_{1}, U_{2} \subset \bar{K}^{n}\), the following properties hold: (i) \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \Longrightarrow V\left(\mathfrak{a}_{1}\right) \supset V\left(\mathfrak{a}_{2}\right)\). (ii) \(U_{1} \subset U_{2} \Longrightarrow I\left(U_{1}\right) \supset I\left(U_{2}\right)\). (iii) \(V\left(\sum_{i} \mathfrak{a}_{i}\right)=\bigcap_{i} V\left(\mathfrak{a}_{i}\right)\). (iv) \(V\left(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \cdot \mathfrak{a}_{2}\right)=V\left(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \cap \mathfrak{a}_{2}\right)=V\left(\mathfrak{a}_{1}\right) \cup V\left(\mathfrak{a}_{2}\right)\).

Let \(R\) be a Noetherian ring. Then the polynomial ring \(R[Y]\) in a variable \(Y\) is Noetherian as well. In particular, the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\) in finitely many variables over a field \(K\) is Noetherian.

The mappings \(I(\cdot)\) and \(V(\cdot)\) define mutually inverse and inclusion-inverting bijections between the set of algebraic subsets of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) and the set of reduced ideals in \(K[X]\).

Let \(\mathfrak{a}\) be an ideal of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\) and let \(V(\mathfrak{a})\) be the corresponding zero set in \(\bar{K}^{n}\). Then \(I(V(\mathfrak{a}))=\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\). In other words, a polynomial \(f \in K[X]\) vanishes on \(V(\mathfrak{a})\) precisely when a power \(f^{r}\) belongs to \(\mathfrak{a}\).

Let \(K\) be an algebraically closed field. An ideal \(\mathfrak{m}\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\) is maximal if and only if there exists a point \(x=\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)\) in \(K^{n}\) such that \(\mathfrak{m}=\left(X_{1}-x_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}-x_{n}\right)\). In particular, \(V(\mathfrak{m})=\{x\}\) and \(I(x)=\mathfrak{m}\) in this case.
